CH ST 1A.title: Introduction to Chicano/a Studies
CH ST 1A.description: Introduction to the historical and contemporary development of the Chicano/a community. Course is interdisciplinary in nature. Focuses by quarter on A. history, B. gender, and C. culture.

CH ST 1B.title: Introduction to Chicano/a Studies
CH ST 1B.description: Introduction to the historical and contemporary development of the Chicano/a community. Course is interdisciplinary in nature. Focuses by quarter on A. history, B. gender, and C. culture.

CH ST 1C.title: Introduction to Chicano/a Studies
CH ST 1C.description: Introduction to the historical and contemporary development of the Chicano/a community. Course is interdisciplinary in nature. Focuses by quarter on A. history, B. gender, and C. culture.

CH ST 9A.title: Classic Maya History
CH ST 9A.description: An introduction to ancient Maya culture through its history recovered from hieroglyphic texts. Emphasis is on political history, but religion, art, and science are considered as well.

CH ST 10.title: Introduction to Chicana/o-Latina/o History
CH ST 10.description: Covers the contours of the Chicana/o-Latina/o historical experience. Beginning with the indigenous pre-Columbian societies of Mexico and Central America, this course also includes the Spanish colonial era of Mexico, Mexican independence, the U.S.-  Mexico War, the annexation of Mexico's northern regions to the U.S., the commencement of mass Mexican immigration, the second-  generation experience, the Mexican American civil rights movement, the Chicano Movement, and the post-movement Latino Generation.

CH ST 12.title: Introduction to Chicano Spanish
CH ST 12.description: The course will introduce students to Chicano Spanish and helps them to improve oral and written skills, distinguish between standard speech and popular variants, and to learn the Chicano Spanish lexicon.

CH ST 13.title: Critical Introduction to Ancient Mesoamerica
CH ST 13.description: Broad survey of ancient Mesoamerica (Olmec, Zapotec, Teotihuacan, Maya, Aztec). Investigates these cultures along with factors that have influenced their contemporary interpretation, including the forms of data available and contexts and motivations of the people who have generated them.

CH ST 91AAZZ.title: Special Topics in Chicano Studies
CH ST 91AAZZ.comments: Course may be taken up to three times (12 units) providing the letter designations are different.
CH ST 91AAZZ.description: Designed to allow courses of varying topics in areas of expertise of visiting professors to broaden opportunities for students. Examples might be: immigration, Native American, Mexican, or Latin American influences on the Chicano, legal issues, the migrants.

CH ST 99.title: Independent Studies
CH ST 99.comments: Students are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
CH ST 99.description: Independent study under the guidance of a faculty member in the department. Course offers students the opportunity to undertake independent study or work in a group.

CH ST 101C.title: Teaching for Social Justice
CH ST 101C.prereq_description: Upper-division standing. At least one course in any of the these departments: Asian American Studies, Black Studies, Chicana/o Studies, or Feminist Studies
CH ST 101C.comments: AS AM 101C, BL ST 101C, CH ST 101C, and FEMST 101C are cross-listed.
CH ST 101C.description: This interdisciplinary course will highlight how a curriculum focusing on racial, ethnic, gender, and LGBTQ studies is central to teaching and learning within diverse societal contexts. This grounding is essential for K-12 teachers in History and English/Literature. Through a social justice framework, students will learn how classrooms are enhanced by Ethnic and Feminist Studies, placing graduates within the forefront of educational initiatives that position teaching and learning within an inclusive and equitable paradigm.

CH ST 103.title: Chicana/o and Latina/o Media and Popular Culture
CH ST 103.description: Surveys theories and practices of consumption of ethnic media in relation to U.S. ethnic identity with an emphasis on telenovelas, "border" films, U.S. Spanish-language music sales, and bilingual media.

CH ST 107.title: Politics of Language, Accent, and Translation
CH ST 107.description: Examines how language politics are magnified in public policy, public culture, and the mainstream media, and how accents work to racialize Latinos.

CH ST 108.title: Transnational Chicana and Chicano Studies
CH ST 108.description: Surveys how Chicana/o scholars position themselves within the interdisciplinary field of transnational literature as ethnic U.S. subjects. Reviews patterns and scholarship of transnational migration.

CH ST 109.title: Indigenous People and the Nation State in the Americas
CH ST 109.prereq_description: CHST 1A, OR CHST 1B, OR CHST 1C, OR ANTH 2
CH ST 109.description: The changing relationship between indigenous people and the state. Compare the differences and similarities between indigenous peoples' mobilizations in the cases of Canada, USA, Ecuador, Chile, Guatemala, Bolivia and Mexico.

CH ST 110.title: Research Methods in Chicano Studies
CH ST 110.prereq_description: Chicano Studies 1A or 1B or 1C or upper-division standing.
CH ST 110.description: Using Chicano studies topics, the course will introduce students to: (1) the epistemology of scientific inquiry (its history and contemporary movements); (2) the strengths and weaknesses of quantitative and qualitative methodologies; and (3) the mechanisms of research design (transforming an idea into a research plan).

CH ST 111.title: Race and Representation in Latina/o Film
CH ST 111.description: Interrogation of the ways in which Latinas and Latinos are represented in cinema. Explore early portrayals of Latinas/os in film history and then contemporary films with a focus on race, class, gender and sexuality. Employing multiple aesthetic and disciplinary approaches, analyze commercial alongside independent films with attention to the market-driven and political mandates of these projects. Focus on films by both Latina/o filmmakers and non-Latina/o filmmakers interrogating multifarious points of entry of these artists.

CH ST 112.title: Methodology of the Oppressed
CH ST 112.prereq_description: Chicano Studies 1A or 1B or 1C or upper-division standing.

CH ST 113.title: Critical Introduction to Ancient Mesoamerica
CH ST 113.description: Broad survey of ancient Mesoamerica (Olmec, Zapotec, Teotihuacan, Maya, Aztec). Investigates these cultures along with factors that have influenced their contemporary interpretation, including the forms of data available and contexts and motivations of the people who have generated them.

CH ST 114.title: Cultural and Critical Theory
CH ST 114.prereq_description: Chicano Studies 1A or 1B or 1C or upper-division standing.
CH ST 114.description: Introduction to the various modes, techniques, terminologies, and methodologies fundamental to cultural studies.

CH ST 115N.title: Indigenous Studies Internships
CH ST 115N.prereq_description: Any Ethnic Studies or Feminist Studies course recommended (not required).
CH ST 115N.comments:
Open to non-majors.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated two additional times for credit for a maximum of 15 total units.

CH ST 117.title: Aztec and Maya Mythologies
CH ST 117.description: Explores ancient Mesoamerican mythology in both its indigenous and modern Chicana representations from archeological, historical, and Chicano perspectives. Emphasizes consideration of the various forms by which mythologies are maintained.

CH ST 118.title: The Scientific Revolution and Non-Western Epistemologies
CH ST 118.prereq_description: Chicano Studies 1A or 1B or 1C or upper-division standing.
CH ST 118.description: Overview of the Scientific Revolution and its impact both within Western Europe and outside of the Mediterranean region through colonialism. Contrast of resulting "Western" scientific perspective with non-Western epistemologies, principally of the indigenous Western Hemisphere.

CH ST 124.title: Introduction to U.S. Xicana(x) and Latinx Public Art and Studio
CH ST 124.prereq_description: Chicano Studies 1A or 1B or 1C. Concurrent enrollment in Chicano Studies 124L required.
CH ST 124.description: Explores examples of public and site-specific artwork created by Chicano/Latinx artists challenging museum and gallery spaces. The history of displacement and marginalization traditionally suffered by Chicano/Latinx communities had lead these artists to create public art as a form of decolonization.

CH ST 124G.title: The Virgin of Guadalupe: From Tilma to Tattoo
CH ST 124G.description: Beginning with her precursors in the Old and New World, this course approaches Guadalupe as a tool to pry open questions central to Mexican and Chicano/a identity. For some, she is a compassionate mother-figure with characteristics once attributed to powerful pre-Columbian goddesses; for others, she is a feminist champion of political revolution and human rights. The course concentrates on the most compelling contexts in which Guadalupe has been called on to negotiate religious, racial, sexual, and national identity.

CH ST 124L.title: Introduction to U.S. Xicana(x) and Latinx Public Art and Studio
CH ST 124L.prereq_description: Concurrent enrollment in Chicano Studies 124 required.
CH ST 124L.description: After visiting the Chicana/Latinx museum and gallery spaces, the lab supports students in producing their own public and site-specific artwork. Other students describe, arrange, and curate a gallery showing by the end of the quarter.

CH ST 125A.title: MeXicana/o(x) Art History (1848-1975)
CH ST 125A.prereq_description: Chicano Studies 1A or 1B or 1C or upper-division standing.
CH ST 125A.description: A look at the body of Chicana/o artistic production, from mid-1960 to the mid-1970's, through an examination of the historical, aesthetic and philosophical foundations of Chicana/o art theory and practice that evolved out of Mexican and Latin American Modernism. Revisits Mexican modernist ideas on race and gender, culture, identity and nation, revolution and class conflict; and sifts through the Indigenous values and concepts Chicana/os encountered through their study of Mexican history and culture during the mid 1960's and early 1970's.

CH ST 125B.title: Contemporary Chicano and Chicana Art
CH ST 125B.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Art History 125B or 146.
CH ST 125B.description: Examination and appraisal of the Chicana/o art movement within the context of contemporary American art and the contemporary art of Mexico. A survey of major Chicano and Chicana artists and developments in Chicano painting, sculpture, graphic, and conceptual art from the late 1960's to the present.

CH ST 126.title: Educating the Native
CH ST 126.description: We look at different educational projects, such as Indian boarding schools, English-only laws, the "indirect rule" of the British colonies. We address the not-always-clear line between education as a form of social control or as a form of liberation.

CH ST 127.title: Art Praxis - Chicana/o Art Education as Social Practice: Politics, Methods,and Practice for Community-Based Work
CH ST 127.prereq_description: Chicano Studies 1A or 1B or 1C or upper-division standing.  Concurrent enrollment in Chicano Studies 127L required.
CH ST 127.description: Examines the work and ideas that artists of color have integrated into their art practice to educate, expose, and address the concerns of 'oppressed communities,' such as racism, the effects of war, state violence, labor struggles, forced migration, immigration, sexism, and economic disparity. This overview is the basis for examining the intersections and differences that have informed the strategies and tactics we explore in the development of our approach to community art practice.

CH ST 127L.title: Art Praxis - Chicana/o Art Education as Social Practice: Politics, Methods,and Practice for Community-Based Work Lab
CH ST 127L.prereq_description: Chicano Studies 1A or 1B or 1C or upper-division standing.  Concurrent enrollment in Chicano Studies 127 required.
CH ST 127L.description: Examines the work and ideas that artists of color have integrated into their art practice to educate, expose, and address the concerns of 'oppressed communities,' such as racism, the effects of war, state violence, labor struggles, forced migration, immigration, sexism, and economic disparity. This overview is the basis for examining the intersections and differences that have informed the strategies and tactics we explore in the development of our approach to community art practice.

CH ST 128.title: Xicana(x) Visual Traditions
CH ST 128.description: Introduces students to the development of art as a social practice specifically in the MeXicana[x], Latina[x], and Indigenous communities. Students will study the oral/visual traditions, art forms, and costumbres that are still in practice today in the transnational communities surrounding us.

CH ST 130.title: Imaging (Imagining) Chicanas/os: A Critical Media Literacy Seminar
CH ST 130.description: Presents a critical historical overview of mainstream entertainment media images of Chicanas and Chicanos, with an emphasis on educational impact of such portrayals. Students examine how historical, social, psychological, political, and economic forces construct imaginary Chicanas/os through media images.

CH ST 131.title: Chicanas/os in Higher Education
CH ST 131.comments: Open to non-majors. Quarters usually offered: Fall.
CH ST 131.description: The three main goals of the course are to: 1) provide a sociodemographic profile of Chicanas/os in higher education; 2) to review the different theories used to explain the current state of Chicanas/os in higher education; and 3) review policies that increase Chicanas/os' access to higher education.

CH ST 132.title: A History of Chicana/o Education
CH ST 132.description: A theoretical and empirical overview of Chicana/o educational issues in the United States. Special emphasis on analyzing the ways in which race, gender, class, and immigrant status affect Chicana/o educational attainment and achievement.

CH ST 133.title: Struggles for Equality in Chicana/o Education
CH ST 133.description: Investigates Chicana/o struggles for educational equality in the U.S. Presentations, discussions, written assignments analyze historical and contemporary examples of Chicana/o communities responding to and resisting subordination based on intersections of race with gender, class, language, immigrant status, and sexuality.

CH ST 134.title: Chicana/o Curricula K-12: Theory into Practice
CH ST 134.comments: Field work component includes a one hour per week discussion section.
CH ST 134.description: Addresses academic literature in bilingual and multicultural education in the context of hands-on experience in Chicana/o educational settings. Fieldwork encompasses students working as part of a research team in Santa Barbara area schools to link academic knowledge with K-12 practice.

CH ST 135.title: Critical Race Theory in Chicana/o Education
CH ST 135.description: Examines Critical Race Theory (CRT) as an emerging analytical framework in the field of education. Course investigates how a CRT framework might address and challenge the impacts of race, class, gender, language, immigrant status, accent, and sexual orientation on Chicana/o, Latina/o educational attainment and achievement.

CH ST 135H.title: Critical Race Theory in Chicana/o Education (Honors)
CH ST 135H.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; and consent of instructor.
CH ST 135H.comments: Concurrently offered with ChSt 135. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall. Not open for credit for students who have completed CH ST 135.
CH ST 135H.description: Lecture is concurrent with Chicana/o Studies 135, along with a weekly honors seminar, requiring additional assignments and intensive discussion of the readings. Intended for highly motivated and well prepared students.

CH ST 136.title: Oral History: Theories and Methods
CH ST 136.description: Survey of oral history as a theoretical and methodological practice, including the "testimonio" tradition. Through readings, discussions, and a small field studies component, the politics of memory and truth, and the challenges and pleasures of oral history work are considered.

CH ST 137.title: Chicana/o Oral Traditions
CH ST 137.description: Introduces students to Chicana/o oral traditions. Contemporary forms of Chicano oral poetry, oral narrative, and drama are examined in addition to more ephemeral forms such as cabula, choteo, joke-telling, or dichos.

CH ST 138.title: Barrio Popular Culture
CH ST 138.description: Explores various manifestations of popular and mass culture in Chicano urban and semi-rural communities throughout the Southwest. Both secular and religious cultural phenomena are analyzed (lowriders, saints, music, etc.). Relationships to mainstream culture is examined.

CH ST 138H.title: Barrio Popular Culture (Honors)
CH ST 138H.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; and consent of instructor
CH ST 138H.comments: Concurrently offered with ChSt 138. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall.
CH ST 138H.description: Lecture is concurrent with Chicana/o Studies 138, along with a weekly honors seminar, requiring additional assignments and intensive discussion of the readings. Intended for highly motivated and well prepared students.

CH ST 140.title: Chicana/o Mexican Cultural Heritage
CH ST 140.prereq_description: Chicano Studies 1A or 1B or 1C or upper-division standing.
CH ST 140.description: A panoramic view of present-day Chicana/o traditions analyzed from a Mexican cultural heritage perspective in order to comprehend and appreciate the uniqueness and difference of present-day Chicano/o culture, its achievements, and contribution to the overall American culture.

CH ST 141.title: Central Americans in the United States
CH ST 141.description: Provides an interdisciplinary historical overview of Central American migrations to the U.S., and a cultural and political analysis of resulting individual and group identities. Transnationalism, diasporas, politics, and community building among Central Americans, or "Central American-Americans" are explored.

CH ST 142.title: Salvadoran Diasporas
CH ST 142.description: Review of Salvadoran people's movements across time and space, conscious of the intersection of cultural, social, and economic processes at individual and collective levels. Examines this diaspora and the forging of new identities and vision from this new Cuzcatlan.

CH ST 143.title: Chicano/a Film Studies
CH ST 143.description: Study of Chicano/a cinema to view film as an art form and projection of the filmmaker. Techniques, messages, and ideology stressed as instruments which propose film truth within the context of Chicano/a experience.

CH ST 144.title: The Chicano Community
CH ST 144.description: Origins of the Chicano in rural Mexico; context of contact; patterns of settlement in the United States; the Chicano community, social structure, and social change; acculturation and generational patterns; community leadership and change.

CH ST 146.title: Humor and the Chicana/o Artist
CH ST 146.description: Though Chicana/o art is often associated with serious political and grassroots movements, the use of humor has been a recurring element in its production. Course examines the various instances of humor, irony, and parody in Chicana/o art.

CH ST 148.title: Chicana Art and Feminism
CH ST 148.prereq_description: Chicano Studies 1A or 1B or 1C or upper-division standing.
CH ST 148.description: An overview of contemporary Chicana art and feminist theory from the late 1960s to the present placed within the context of the Chicano movement and other historical events.

CH ST 149.title: Body, Culture, and Power
CH ST 149.description: Exploration of the construction, imaging and experience of the body in light of modern regimes of power/knowledge. Particular attention is paid tothe work of Michel Foucault on disciplinary technologies, medical practicesof ab/normalization, and the emergence of bio-power.

CH ST 149A.title: Race and Science
CH ST 149A.description: Examines the role of science in the construction and management of racialized bodies.

CH ST 151.title: De-Colonizing Feminism
CH ST 151.prereq_description: Department approval required to finalize registration.

CH ST 151H.title: De-Colonizing Feminism (Honors)
CH ST 151H.prereq_description: Chicano Studies 1A or 1B or 1C or upper-division standing.
CH ST 151H.comments: Concurrently offered with Ch St 151. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall.
CH ST 151H.description: Lecture is concurrent with Chicana/o Studies 151 along with a weekly honors seminar, requiring additional assignments and intensive discussion of the readings. Intended for highly motivated and well prepared students.

CH ST 152.title: Postcolonialism
CH ST 152.prereq_description: Chicano Studies 1A or 1B or 1C or upper-division standing.
CH ST 152.description: Exploration of postcolonial theories and their effectiveness as critical tools in discussing Chicano cultural production. Focus will be on Chicano culture as it creates a counter discourse to dominant cultural formations. We will study film, music, visual, performance, and literary arts.

CH ST 153.title: Queer Identities, Communities, and Theories
CH ST 153.description: Examines queer/lgbt community life and death; political and social identities; and multiple gender and sexual expressions. Grounded in narratives of identity and experience, the course explores dimensions of visibility, space, "silence," and politics of exclusion in queer worlds.

CH ST 153H.title: Queer Identities, Communities, and Theories (Honors)
CH ST 153H.prereq_description: Upper-division standing and consent of instructor.
CH ST 153H.comments: Concurrently offered with ChSt 153. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall.
CH ST 153H.description: Lecture is concurrent with Chicana/o Studies 153 along with a weekly honors seminar, requiring additional assignments and intensive discussion of the readings. Intended for highly motivated and well prepared students.

CH ST 154.title: Gender and Sexuality in the Americas
CH ST 154.prereq_description: Departmental approval required to finalize registration.
CH ST 154.description: Examines cultural, social, political and representational aspects of gender and sexuality across the Americas. Organized around various themes--control and repression; the politics and culture of resistance; and sexual transgression as affirmation of marginalized identities--this course challenges conceptions of gender and sexuality across the Americas. Covering topics ranging from normative sexuality, transgender expression, gay sexuality, and lesbian expression, the course is designed to examine developments in gender and sexuality within the U.S. and across the Americas.

CH ST 156.title: Afro-Latina/o Diasporic Performance
CH ST 156.description: Offers an introduction to performance practices rooted in the African diaspora of the Americas focusing on the United States, Latin America, and the Caribbean.  Interrogates identity articulation in dance, music, literature, visual art, and theatrical texts. Examine how performers negotiate race, ethnicity, gender, class, and sexuality with attention to what constitutes "performance." Employing  transnational frameworks, explore how these performances have historically functioned and continue to inspire social transformation and the recovery of shared histories of Afro-Latina/o diasporas.

CH ST 158.title: Spoken Word Art Performance Activism (SWAPA)
CH ST 158.prereq_description: Chicano Studies 1A or 1B or 1C; a previous upper-division course in Chicano Studies.
CH ST 158.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
CH ST 158.description: Spoken wor(ld) art performance activism (SWAPA) introduces students to a method for reading, writing, thinking, and performing before an audience of peers. This method is based on the shaman-witness ritual proposed by Chicana theorist and writer, Gloria Anzaldua.

CH ST 161.title: Latina/o Youths in Global Perspective
CH ST 161.prereq_description: Departmental approval required to finalize registration.
CH ST 161.description: Comparative analysis of Latina and Latino (Latina/o) youths in Europe, Latin America, and the U.S., with special attention to experiences of migration, identity formation, gang membership, race and ethnicity, gender and sexuality, and popular culture and the media.

CH ST 162.title: Xican* Indigena Media
CH ST 162.prereq_description: Chicano Studies 1A or 1B or 1C; two upper division courses in Chicana and Chicano Studies; Concurrent enrollment in Chicano Studies 162L.
CH ST 162.description: Low cost digital tools have created a revolution in video. Course explores creative approaches to practical techniques of independent digital video production. Students establish a production strategy by employing "guerrilla tactics" for creative and unconventional uses of digital machineries.

CH ST 162L.title: Xican* Indigena Media Lab
CH ST 162L.description: Lab for producing guerrilla digital video.

CH ST 165.prereq_description: Departmental approval required to finalize registration.
CH ST 165.description: Using a thematic and interdisciplinary approach, analyzes how society--individuals and institutions--has dealt with "troublesome" or delinquent youths of various racial, ethnic, and class backgrounds, paying particular attention to the experiences of youths of color.

CH ST 166.title: Issues in Contemporary Chicana/o and Latina/o Politics
CH ST 166.prereq_description: Chicano Studies 1A or 1B or 1C or upper-division standing.
CH ST 166.description: Examines various politicized issues relevant to Chicanas/os such as immigrant rights, unauthorized Latina/o residency, Latina/o struggles for LGBT civil rights, English-only movements and nativism, Latina/o political participation, current community and grassroots organizing, and contemporary Chicana/o and Latina/o electoral politics, and urban politics.

CH ST 167.title: Chicana Feminisms
CH ST 167.description: Different feminisms have contributed significantly to contemporary political thought. In this course, students survey the historical development and primary issues of Chicana Feminism, including its practices of political intervention, major writings, and comparisons to other influential feminisms.

CH ST 167H.title: Chicana Feminisms (Honors)
CH ST 167H.comments: Concurrently offered with ChSt 167. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall.
CH ST 167H.description: Lecture is concurrent with Chicana/o Studies 167 along with a weekly honors seminar, requiring additional assignments and intensive discussion of the readings. Intended for highly motivated and well prepared students.

CH ST 168A.title: History of the Chicano
CH ST 168A.prereq_description: History 17A or 17B or 17C or Chicano Studies 1A or 1B or 1C or upper-  division standing.
CH ST 168A.description: The history of the Chicanos from the indigenous/colonial past to 1900. Explores the evolving history of Mexican descent people during the Pre-Columbian, Spanish, Mexican, and the U.S. periods.

CH ST 168B.title: History of the Chicano
CH ST 168B.prereq_description: History 17A or 17B or 17C or Chicano Studies 1A or 1B or 1C or upper-  division standing.
CH ST 168B.description: The history of the Chicanos from 1900 to the present. Explores issues such as immigration, second-generation experience, civil rights struggles, the Chicano Movement, the post-Chicano Movement, the role of women in Chicano history, and the new Latino millennials of the 21st century.

CH ST 168E.title: History of the Chicano Movement
CH ST 168E.prereq_description: Chicano Studies 1A or 1B or 1C or upper-division standing.
CH ST 168E.description: History of the Chicano Movement. An examination of the Chicano movement in the United States from the mid-1960s to the mid-1970s. Topics will include the student movement, the farmworker movement, the Plande Aztlan, the Raza Unida Party, Chicana feminists, the anti-war movement, and Chicanostudies.

CH ST 168EH.title: History of the Chicano Movement (Honors)
CH ST 168EH.prereq_description: Chicano Studies 1A or 1B or 1C or upper-division standing.
CH ST 168EH.comments: Concurrently offered with ChSt 168E. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall.
CH ST 168EH.description: Lecture is concurrent with Chicana/o Studies 168E History of the Chicana/o Movement along with a weekly honors seminar, requiring additional assignments and intensive discussion of the readings. Intended for highly motivated and well prepared students.

CH ST 168F.title: Racism in American History
CH ST 168F.prereq_description: History 17A or 17B or 17C or Chicano Studies 1A or 1B or 1C or Asian
CH ST 168F.description: Racism in American History. This course will examine racism as a major ideological force in defining American society from the colonial era to the 1980s. Major focus will be on the changing nature of racism as an ideology as well as the relationship of racism to specific minority groups such as Afro-American, Native American, Chicanos, and Asian-American.

CH ST 168GQ.title: Minority Autobiography and U.S. History
CH ST 168GQ.prereq_description: Chicana/o Studies 1A or 1B or 1C or History 17A or 17B or 17C.
CH ST 168GQ.description: Seminar utilizes autobiographical or life-story texts by U.S. minority writers to better understand the diversity of U.S. history and the racialized ethnic experience.

CH ST 168I.title: Latino Autobiography and History
CH ST 168I.prereq_description: Chicano Studies 1A or 1B or 1C or upper-division standing.
CH ST 168I.description: Course examines a diverse number of Latino autobiographical texts that reflect the changing nature of the Latino historical experience. Topics covered included issues of race, class, gender, immigration, labor, politics, religion, and culture.

CH ST 168T.title: Latino Religious Traditions in Historical Perspective
CH ST 168T.prereq_description: A previous course in History or Chicano Studies.
CH ST 168T.comments: Same course as History 168T. Not open for credit to students who have taken CH ST 168R or HIST 168R.
CH ST 168T.description: Focuses on the role of religion in the Chicano/Latino historical experience. Includes pre-Columbian traditions, Spanish colonial traditions, religion of the U.S.-Mexico borderlands, immigrant religious traditions, the changing nature of Latino religions in the twentieth century.

CH ST 169.title: Religion and Social Movements - Spirituality, Sacrifice, and the Struggle for Social Justice
CH ST 169.prereq_description: ChSt 1A, 1B, and 1C and upper division standing
CH ST 169.description: An exploration of the relationship between religion and social movements. Special focus placed on individuals such as Gandhi and Cesar Chavez, involved in high-risk nonviolent actions, i.e. hunger strikes (fasts), living in conflict zones, and establishing alternative communities.

CH ST 170A.title: Chicano Political Organizing: Proseminar in Theory & History
CH ST 170A.description: An in-depth examination of the theory and practice of various forms of political organizing. Case studies focus on Chicano/a political organizing in the post-war period with attention to grassroots community organization, electoral politics, and cultural production.

CH ST 171.title: The Brown/Black Metropolis: Race, Class, & Resistance in the City
CH ST 171.description: Traces the transition of Browns/Blacks from a rural urban population and examines trends in family size, language, usage, segregation and social inequality. Issues of urban decay and community conflict are also examined.

CH ST 172.title: Law and Civil Rights
CH ST 172.prereq_description: Chicana/o Studies 1A or 1B or 1C or upper-division standing.
CH ST 172.description: Survey of recent state and federal laws and court decisions affecting the Chicano community. Special consideration is given to landmark cases and decisions. Analysis of opposing views on each case in a historical context.

CH ST 173.title: Immigrant Labor Organizing
CH ST 173.description: Status of growing immigrant population in the counties of Ventura, Santa Barbara, and San Luis Obispo and linkages to agricultural and services unions.

CH ST 174.title: Chicano/a Politics
CH ST 174.description: Political life in the barrio, political behavior of the Chicano community, and representation of Chicanos by elected officials and interest groups.

CH ST 174A.title: The Political Philosophy of Cesar Chavez
CH ST 174A.description: Surveys the political work and philosophy of Cesar Chavez. Elements of his philosophy covered include approaches to race, class, gender, and diversity, basic liberal principles, religious faith and spirituality, and his commitment to nonviolence.

CH ST 176.title: Theories of Social Change and Chicano Political Life
CH ST 176.description: Introduction to classical and contemporary theories of social and political change. Students apply these theoretical frameworks toward understanding specific cases of social and political transformation and continuity which have affected Chicanos/as during the twentieth century.

CH ST 177.title: Globalization and Transnational Social Movements
CH ST 177.description: Analysis of the globalization of the world economy and the social and economic consequences of this process. Examination of the transnational social movements that emerged in response to globalization. Emphasis on Mexico and Central America and role of Chicanos in these movements.

CH ST 178A.title: Global Migration, Transnationalism in Chicana/o Contexts
CH ST 178A.description: This course considers Chicana/o and U.S. Latina/o culture(s) within the context of transnational practices and patterns including both hemispheric and global migration trajectories.

CH ST 179.title: Democracy and Diversity
CH ST 179.description: Introduction to the ancient and modern model of democracy which underpin contemporary democratic life. Special attention given to recent reformulations of our democratic models and how these new approaches relate to Chicano/a political concerns and practices.

CH ST 180.title: Survey of Chicano Literature
CH ST 180.description: The course encompasses a general overview of all genres (poetry, novel, theater, short story and essay) of Chicano literature. A people's socio-historical experiences are examined to understand ethnicity, creativity, and world view.

CH ST 180H.title: Survey of Chicano Literature (Honors)
CH ST 180H.comments: Concurrently offered with ChSt 180. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall. Same course as Spanish 135.
CH ST 180H.description: Lecture is concurrent with Chicana/o Studies 180 Survey of Chicana/o Literature along with a weekly honors seminar, requiring additional assignments and intensive discussion of the readings. Intended for highly motivated and well prepared students.

CH ST 181.title: The Chicano Novel
CH ST 181.description: Reading, analysis, and critique of the contemporary Chicano novel as it pertains to the Chicano experience.

CH ST 182.title: Contemporary Chicano/a Authors
CH ST 182.prereq_description: Chicano Studies 1A or 1B or 1C or upper-division standing.
CH ST 182.description: Detailed reading and critical examination of a limited number of contemporary Chicano/a authors. A more intense study of their literary works than that provided in introductory courses.

CH ST 183.title: Border Narrative
CH ST 183.description: Reading and analysis of U.S./Mexico border narratives (novels, essays, short stories, autobiographies) focusing on the problems associated with relations between countries.

CH ST 184A.title: Chicana Writers
CH ST 184A.prereq_description: Department approval required to finalize registration.
CH ST 184A.description: Examination of literary works by Chicana writers. Feminist theories as well as other contemporary critical theories are applied to the analysis of prose, poetry and dramatic works written by such authors as Sandra Cisneros, Ana Castillo, Helen Viramontes, and others.

CH ST 184AH.title: Chicana Writers (Honors)
CH ST 184AH.comments: Concurrently offered with Ch St 180. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall.
CH ST 184AH.description: Lecture is concurrent with Chicana/o Studies 184A Chicana Writers along with a weekly honors seminar, requiring additional assignments and intensive discussion of the readings. Intended for highly motivated and well prepared students.

CH ST 185.title: De-Colonizing CyberCinema
CH ST 185.prereq_description: Concurrent enrollment in Chicano Studies 185L; upper-division standing.

CH ST 185L.title: De-Colonizing CyberCinema Lab
CH ST 185L.prereq_description: Concurrent enrollment in Chicano Studies 185; upper-division standing.

CH ST 186A.title: Chicano and Mexican Music
CH ST 186A.description: Traditional music from pre-Hispanic to contemporary; regional styles and instruments, indigenous and urban popular styles; social movement music from resistance against Spain, Independence, "La Reforma," the Mexican Revolution, "Cancion Nueva," the Chicano Movement and the contemporary Zapatistas.

CH ST 187.title: Language, Power, and Learning
CH ST 187.prereq_description: Departmental Approval Required to Finalize Registration.
CH ST 187.description: Critical examination of institutional power related to education and linguistic and cultural diversity. Focus on Latino communities; formal and informal learning; family practices; bilingual education; heritage languages; language and labor; language and racism; immigrant languages; racialized varieties of English.

CH ST 188C.title: Chicano Theater Workshop
CH ST 188C.prereq_description: Chicano Studies 1A or 1B or 1C or upper-division standing.
CH ST 188C.description: Reading and analysis of contemporary bilingual chicano plays, in conjunction with acting and technical training. A dramatic piece will be rehearsed and performed.

CH ST 189.title: Immigration and the U.S. Border
CH ST 189.description: Immigration and the U.S. border. An analysis of the socioeconomic and political factors which have determined and continue to form the basis for the development of United States immigration policies and practices toward Mexico and the U.S.-Mexican border.

CH ST 190.title: Introduction to Chicano Poetry and Short Story
CH ST 190.description: Reading and appreciation of Chicano poetry and poets. Analysis and critque of the Chicano short story with discussions on the realities and values presented on the Chicano experience and universe by the author.

CH ST 191AAZZ.title: Special Topics in Chicano Studies
CH ST 191AAZZ.comments: Course may be taken up to three times (12 units) providing the letter designations are different.
CH ST 191AAZZ.description: Designed to allow courses of varying topics in areas of expertise of visiting professors to broaden opportunities for students. Examples might be: immigration, Native American, Mexican, or Latin American influences on the Chicano, legal issues, the migrants.

CH ST 192.title: Group Studies for Advanced Students
CH ST 192.prereq_description: Chicana/o Studies 1A or 1B or 1C or upper-division standing.
CH ST 192.comments: Students may apply a maximum of 8 units of Chicana/o Studies 192/195A-B-C-D/198/199 courses combined to the Chicana/o Studies major.

CH ST 192HR.prereq_description: Chicana/o Studies 1A or 1B or 1C or upper-division standing.

CH ST 193.title: Senior Seminar
CH ST 193.prereq_description: Two courses in Chicana/o Studies; consent of instructor; and senior standing.
CH ST 193.comments: Designed for majors. To be offered intermittently.
CH ST 193.description: Capstone course for Chicana and Chicano Studies majors. Goal is to produce a thoroughly documented and professionally crafted Chicana/o Studies research paper (or creative project).

CH ST 194A.title: Ethnic Studies Teacher Education Seminar
CH ST 194A.prereq_description: At least one course in one of these departments: Asian American Studies, Black Studies, Chicana/o Studies, Feminist Studies.
CH ST 194A.description: Designed for students who are Black Studies, Chicana/o Studies, Asian American and/or Feminist Studies majors in the EXITO (Educational eXcellence and Inclusion Training Opportunities) program. Central to the year-long seminar will be preparations for students' pursuit for a career as K-12 Ethnic Studies educators. Students will have direct assistance for preparing and applying to Masters/Teacher Education Programs as well as professionalization workshops.

CH ST 194B.title: Ethnic Studies Teacher Education Seminar
CH ST 194B.prereq_description: At least one course in one of these departments: Asian American Studies, Black Studies, Chicana/o Studies, Feminist Studies.
CH ST 194B.description: Designed for students who are Black Studies, Chicana/o Studies, Asian American and/or Feminist Studies majors in the EXITO (Educational eXcellence and Inclusion Training Opportunities) program. Central to the year-long seminar will be preparations for students' pursuit for a career as K-12 Ethnic Studies educators. Students will have direct assistance for preparing and applying to Masters/Teacher Education Programs as well as professionalization workshops.

CH ST 194C.title: Ethnic Studies Teacher Education Seminar
CH ST 194C.prereq_description: At least one course in one of these departments: Asian American Studies, Black Studies, Chicana/o Studies, Feminist Studies.
CH ST 194C.description: Designed for students who are Black Studies, Chicana/o Studies, Asian American and/or Feminist Studies majors in the EXITO (Educational eXcellence and Inclusion Training Opportunities) program. Central to the year-long seminar will be preparations for students' pursuit for a career as K-12 Ethnic Studies educators. Students will have direct assistance for preparing and applying to Masters/Teacher Education Programs as well as professionalization workshops.

CH ST 195A.title: Community Studies and Outreach Initiatives
CH ST 195A.comments: Open to non-majors. Students may apply a maximum of 8 units of Chicana/o Studies 192/195A-B-  C-D/198/199 courses combined to the Chicana/o Studies major.
CH ST 195A.description: Internship in contemporary urban problems and decision-making processes as they affect the Chicana/o community. Student individually assigned, instructed and supervised in fieldwork involving practical experience in decision-making unit of local agencies serving Latina/o,Chicana/o communities.

CH ST 195B.title: Community Studies and Outreach Initiatives
CH ST 195B.comments: Students may apply a maximum of 8 units of Chicana/o Studies 192/195A-B-C-D/198/199 courses combined to the Chicana/o Studies major.
CH ST 195B.description: Internship in contemporary urban problems and decision-making processes as they affect the Chicana/o community. Student individually assigned, instructed and supervised in fieldwork involving practical experience in decision-making unit of local governmental social service, or of community liaison agencies.

CH ST 195C.title: Community Studies and Outreach Initiatives
CH ST 195C.comments: Students may apply a maximum of 8 units of Chicana/o Studies 192/195A-B-C-D/198/199 courses combined to the Chicana/o Studies major.
CH ST 195C.description: Internship in contemporary urban problems and decision-making processes as they affect the Chicana/o community. Students are individually assigned, instructed and supervised in fieldwork involving practical experience in decision-making unit of local governmental social service, or of community liaison agencies.

CH ST 195D.title: Community Studies and Outreach Initiatives
CH ST 195D.comments: Students may apply a maximum of 8 units of Chicana/o Studies 192/195A-B-C-D/198/199 courses combined to the Chicana/o Studies major.
CH ST 195D.description: Internship in contemporary urban problems and decision-  making processes as they affect the Chicana/o community. Students are individually assigned, instructed and supervised in fieldwork involving practical experience in decision-making unit of local governmental social service, or of community liaison agencies.

CH ST 197HA.title: Honors Project Seminar
CH ST 197HA.prereq_description: Acceptance into the Chicana and Chicano Studies honors program; senior standing; consent of department; open to Chicana and Chicano Studies majors only.
CH ST 197HA.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Fall.
CH ST 197HA.description: Seminar for the development of the honors research project. Emphasis is on the design of the project and the establishment of methodologies to be utilized. Background and initial research is undertaken.

CH ST 197HB.title: Honors Project Research
CH ST 197HB.prereq_description: Chicana/o Studies 197HA; acceptance into the Chicana and Chicano Studies honors program; senior standing; consent of department; open to Chicana and Chicano Studies majors only.
CH ST 197HB.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter.
CH ST 197HB.description: Independent research comprising the bulk of the data acquisition and organization for the honors project.

CH ST 197HC.title: Honors Project Writing
CH ST 197HC.prereq_description: Chicana/o Studies 197HB; acceptance into Chicana and Chicano Studies honors program; senior standing; consent of department; open to Chicana and Chicano Studies majors only.
CH ST 197HC.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring.
CH ST 197HC.description: Allows students to complete the writing of the honors thesis. Time is allotted to prepare a presentation of the project before an audience of peers and faculty members.

CH ST 198.title: Readings in Chicano Studies
CH ST 198.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; completion of two prior upper-division courses in Chicano Studies; consent of instructor.
CH ST 198.comments: Students are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined. Students may apply a maximum of 8 unitsof Chicano Studies 192/194A-B-C-D/195A-B-C-D/196A-B-C-D/198/199 courses comined to the Chicano Studies major.
CH ST 198.description: Readings in Chicano Studies under the guidance of a faculty member in the department. Students must prepare a short plan of study and have it approved by the sponsoring faculty member.

CH ST 199.title: Independent Studies
CH ST 199.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; completion of two upper-division courses in Chicana/o Studies.
CH ST 199.comments: Students are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined. Students may apply a maximum of 8 unitsof Chicana/o Studies 192/195A-B-C-D/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined to the Chicana/o Studies major.
CH ST 199.description: Independent studies in Chicana/o students under the guidance of a faculty member in the department. Students wishing to enroll should prepare a short plan of study.

CH ST 199RA.title: Independent Research Assistance in Chicana/o Studies
CH ST 199RA.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in Chicana/o Studies; consent of instructor and department.
CH ST 199RA.comments: Students are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined. Chicana/o Studies 199RA may not be usedfor credit in the major.
CH ST 199RA.description: Coursework consists of faculty supervised research assistance.

CH ST 200A.title: History and Narrativity
CH ST 200A.description: Examines critical theories and methods in the production of historical narratives, social myths, and ideologies of racialization and ethnicity. Special attention is given to employment strategies, tropes, and allegorical forms in the construction of historical events and narratives.

CH ST 200B.title: Cultural Texts
CH ST 200B.description: Explores critical theories and methods in the production of cultural knowledge in the humanities. Special attention is given to interdisciplinary articulations with theories and methods in the social sciences.

CH ST 200C.title: Social Processes
CH ST 200C.description: Explores critical theories and methods in the production of knowledge relevant to social, political, economic, and institutional structures. Special attention is given to interdisciplinary articulations with theories and methods in the humanities.

CH ST 210.title: Research Seminar
CH ST 210.description: Introduces students to the practice of original research in the interdisciplinary field of Chicana and Chicano Studies, including articulating a research problem, placing it within theoretical discussions, selecting appropriate methods, and analyzing and writing data, results, and/or findings.

CH ST 220.title: Interdisciplinary Methods
CH ST 220.description: A critical introduction to a broad range of approaches and methodologies used in Chicana and Chicano Studies. These methods include (but are not limited to) fieldwork, archival and historical research, textual analysis, action research, visual production, political economy, and statistics.

CH ST 222.title: Ethnicity and Race in the Americas
CH ST 222.description: Identifies different racial projects, of how "ethnicity" and "race" are understood in specific contexts. Special attention is put on the ideas of mestizaje, indigenismo and development, and the role that played in the racial projects of Latin America.

CH ST 230C.title: Ethnography & Ethnographic Methods
CH ST 230C.description: This course examines the epistemology, ethics, and politics of ethnographic fieldwork and is designed to provide students with the methodological tools to conduct ethnographic research. Through close reading and seminar discussions, students reflect on the origins of ethnographic inquiry and engage with decolonial responses to Western ethnographic inquiry. Having developed a critical understanding of ethnographic research as theory and method in the first half of the course, students develop and workshop their own ethnographic research project and gain hands-on experience collecting, analyzing, and writing up ethnographic data.

CH ST 238.title: Barrio Popular Culture
CH ST 238.comments: Concurrently offered with CHST 138 and CHST 138H. Quarters usually offered:Winter, Spring, Fall.
CH ST 238.description: A graduate level exploration of the various manifestations of popular and mass culture in Chicano urban and semi-rural communities throughout the Southwest. Both secular and religious cultural phenomena are analyzed (lowriders, saints, music, etc.). Relationships to mainstream culture are examined.

CH ST 240.title: Chicana and Chicano Studies Colloquium
CH ST 240.description: A year-long, bi-monthly colloquium required for all doctoral Chicana and Chicano Studies graduate students. Designed to provide cohort-identity and faculty-student exchange, the colloquium provides students with the opportunity to present research papers, hear guest lecturers, and see faculty presentations.

CH ST 249.title: Spanish for Graduate Students
CH ST 249.description: Provides graduate students with basic and broad knowledge to familiarize them with texts from a  variety of disciplines. Course will provide training in rules, vocabulary and linguistic tips.

CH ST 250A.title: Theory of the Chicana/o Novel
CH ST 250A.description: Examines theoretical approaches to the Chicana/o novel. Combines questions and methods pertaining to specific texts of this genre: structuralism, formalism, Marxism, postmodernism, semiotics, cultural studies, and postcolonial studies. Centers notions of nationhood, identity, space, gender, and culture.

CH ST 250B.title: Literary History in Chicana/o Literature
CH ST 250B.description: Attempts to explain factors and parameters contributing to literary history in Chicana and Chicana literature from the colonial period (1540s) to the contemporary period (twenty-first century). Each major period is characterized and studied through a representative text.

CH ST 251.title: De-Colonizing Feminism
CH ST 251.comments: Concurrently offered with CHST 151 and CHST 151H. Quarters usually offered:Winter, Spring, Fall.
CH ST 251.description: Key writings by US feminists-of-color have transformed intellectual and cultural production, and re-generated new modes of de-colonizing philosophy.  Graduate students write a substantial paper. They also participate in organizing and leading class discussions on a rotating basis.

CH ST 252A.title: Indigenous Texts
CH ST 252A.description: Treats translations of primary indigenous documents. Investigates the oral performance inherent to written indigenous records. Attention focuses on the Popol Vuh and the Codex Chimalpopoca, but Classic Maya hieroglyphic texts and Aztec codices are considered as well.

CH ST 253.title: Queer Identities, Communities & Theories
CH ST 253.comments: Concurrently offered with CHST 153 & CHST 153H. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall.
CH ST 253.description: Examines queer/LGBT community life and death; political and social identities; and multiple gender expressions and sexual desires. Grounded in narratives of identity and experience, the course explores dimensions of visibility, space, silence, and the politics of Chicana/o and Latina/o exclusion.

CH ST 256.title: Contemporary Readings in Chicana-o Latina-o Indigenous Studies
CH ST 256.description: Focuses on recent publications covering different fields in Chicana-o Latina-o Indigenous studies in the Humanities, Social and/or Natural Sciences.

CH ST 259.title: The Chicano Movement: New Historical Perspectives
CH ST 259.description: Focuses on the Chicano Movement of the 1960s and 1970s and the developing historiographical literature on the Movement. Topics to be covered include Chicanismo, the student movement, the anti-war movement, and La Chicana.

CH ST 260A.title: Seminar in Chicana and Chicano History
CH ST 260A.description: First part of a two-quarter research seminar exploring various facets of Chicano history, concentrating on the twentieth century. Examination of literature and projects covering immigration, labor, women, the Mexican-American, and the Chicano movement.

CH ST 261A.title: Chicana/o Education
CH ST 261A.description: A theoretical and empirical overview of Chicana/o educational issues in the U.S., analyzing effects of race, gender, class, language, sexuality, and immigrant status on attainment and achievement. Examination of social, political, economic, and historical contexts of Chicana/o educational experiences.

CH ST 261B.title: Imaging (Imagining) Chicanas/os
CH ST 261B.description: Using visual sociology, course examines film, television, and print media for their inclusion, exclusion, or distortion of Chicanas/os, and the impacts of these images. Historical examination of how society, economy, and politics shape popular discourse.

CH ST 265.title: Reading Anzaldua: Text, Context, and Interpretation
CH ST 265.description: Seminar surveys the major and minor works of Chicana feminist thinker Gloria Anzaldua and considers the influence that her work has had in a range of disciplines, from Chicana/o Studies and queer theory to political science and philosophy.

CH ST 266.title: Theories of Mestizaje: Critical Perspectives from the   Americas
CH ST 266.description: Mestizaje has been one of the longest racial projects in the American continent, both as a de facto phenomena and as an ideology. This course critically engages with contemporary debates. Explores Mestizaje as resistance, as well as domination.

CH ST 267.title: Chicana Feminisms
CH ST 267.comments: Concurrently offered with CHST 167 and CHST 167H. Quarters usually offered:Winter, Spring, Fall.
CH ST 267.description: Different feminisms have contributed significantly to contemporary political thought. In this course, graduate students survey the historical development and primary issues of Chicana Feminism, including its practices of political intervention, major writings, and comparisons to other influential feminisms.

CH ST 268E.title: History of the Chicana/o Movement
CH ST 268E.comments: Concurrently offered with CSHT 168E and CHST 168EH. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall.
CH ST 268E.description: An examination of the Chicano movement in the United States from the mid-1960s to the mid-1970s. Topics will include the student movement, the farmworker movement, the Plan de Aztlan, the Raza Unida Party, Chicana feminists, the anti-war movement, and Chicano Studies.

CH ST 268F.title: Racism in American History
CH ST 268F.comments: Concurrently offered with CHST 168F and CHST 168FH. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall.
CH ST 268F.description: Racism as a major ideological force in defining American society from the colonial era to the present. Major focus will be in the changing nature of racism as an ideology as well as the relationship of racism to specific minority groups such as Chicanas/os, Latinas/os, African-Americans, Asian-Americans, Native Americans, and Arab-Americans.

CH ST 270.title: Globalization and Transnational Social Movements
CH ST 270.description: An examination of globalization in the world economy and its impact on Central America, Mexico, and the Chicano/Latino community in the U.S. Topics include the historical and contemporary nature of capitalism, the WTO, the IMP, the World Bank, and neoliberalism.

CH ST 271.title: Globalization and Immigration
CH ST 271.description: Tracks the migration of people and cultures across national boundaries, focusing on the itinerary of Mexican migrations to the U.S., with selected examples of migrations into Europe. Attention is paid to the changing significance of the nation.

CH ST 274A.title: Oral History: Theories, Ethics, and Methods
CH ST 274A.description: A survey of the theory and practice of oral history methodologies, including the testimonio tradition in Latin America. Considers the politics of memory and truth, evidence and experience, and the challenges and pleasures of oral history work among subordinated communities.

CH ST 279.title: The Brown/Black Metropolis: Race, Class, & Resistance in the City
CH ST 279.comments: Concurrently offered with CHST 171 & CHST 171H. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall.
CH ST 279.description: Traces the transition of Browns/Blacks from a rural urban population and examines trends in family size, language, usage, segregation and social inequality.  Issues of urban decay and community conflict are also examined.

CH ST 280.title: Critical Race Theory in Education
CH ST 280.description: Utilizing a critical race theory framework, the course examines education with an emphasis on the intercentricity of race/racism with other forms of subordination and the power of experiential knowledge to challenge traditional theories, concepts, methods, and data.

CH ST 280A.title: Survey of Chicana/o Literature
CH ST 280A.comments: Concurrently offered with CHST 180 and CHST 180H. Quarters usually offered:Winter, Spring, Fall.
CH ST 280A.description: General overview of all genres (poetry, novel, theater, short story and essay) of Chicano literature. A people's socio-historical experiences are examined to understand ethnicity, creativity, and world view.

CH ST 281A.title: A People's History of Los Angeles: Race, Class, and Resistance in the City
CH ST 281A.description: The history of Los Angeles from the perspective of people of color, women, queer people, and working-class people.  Brown-black relations and contemporary social movements in Los Angeles will be especially emphasized.

CH ST 284A.title: Chicana Writers
CH ST 284A.comments: Concurrently offered with CHST 184A and CHST 184AH. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall. Creating concurrent graduate companion course for CHST 184A and CHST 184AH. CHST 284A will differ from the undergraduate courses, even thought they are offered concurrently.
CH ST 284A.description: Graduates will examine and analyze literary works by Chicana writers. Feminist theories as well as other contemporary critical theories are applied to the analysis of prose, poetry and dramatic words written by well-known Chicana writers.

CH ST 285.title: Oppositional Texts of the 1960s and the Chicano Movement
CH ST 285.description: This seminar will focus on key oppositional texts and writers of the 1960s that influenced the Chicano Movement. Writers will include Frantz Fanon, Stokely Carmichael, Robert Blauner, Malcolm X, Che Guevarra, and others.

CH ST 501.title: Teaching Assistant and Associate Training
CH ST 501.comments: Units earned do not apply toward completion of advanced degrees. S/U grading only. Required of all teaching assistants in Chicana and Chicano Studies.
CH ST 501.description: Supervised teaching of lower division Chicana/o Studies courses. Required participation in occasional workshops related to teaching.

CH ST 502.title: Teaching Assistant Practicum
CH ST 502.comments: Units earned do not apply toward completion of advanced degrees. S/U grading only.
CH ST 502.description: Introduces incoming Teaching Assistants to key campus resources and services available to graduate and undergraduate students. It is intended to foster an ongoing dialogue about teaching within the academy.

CH ST 592.title: Directed Reading
CH ST 592.description: Course content variable; may be repeated. Special readings selected under guidance of individual instructor to help students make up particular gaps in their intellectual backgrounds that are pertinent to their graduate program.

CH ST 594AAZZ.title: Special Topics
CH ST 594AAZZ.description: Special seminar on research subjects of current interest.

CH ST 596.title: Directed Reading and Research
CH ST 596.comments: May be repeated an indefinite number of times due to independent nature of course.
CH ST 596.description: An independent research or individually guided tutorial in an area not covered by existing courses.

CH ST 597.title: Individual Study for Master's or Ph.D. Examinations for Advancement to Candidacy
CH ST 597.comments: May be repeated an indefinite number of times due to independent nature of course.
CH ST 597.description: Normally taken with the student's committee chair in preparation for Master's or Ph.D. examinations. Units do not count toward graduate degrees.

CH ST 598.title: Master's Research and Writing
CH ST 598.comments: May be repeated an indefinite number of times due to independent nature of course.
CH ST 598.description: Open to graduate students conduction master's research.

CH ST 599.title: Dissertation Research and Writing
CH ST 599.prereq_description: Open to graduate students conducting doctoral thesis research.
CH ST 599.comments: May be repeated an indefinite number of times due to independent nature of thesis research and writing.
CH ST 599.description: Open to graduate students conducting doctoral research.
